column2: Crown Sovereignty on Hereditary Titles
Laws governing the right of a ruler to interfere in the ownership and succession of hereditary titles.
Limited Sovereignty
The ruler is not under any circumstances allowed to interfere in the ownership and succession of hereditary titles.
Limited
Balanced Sovereignty

The ruler is allowed to legally seize hereditary titles from traitors and unlawful subjects. Vassal title inheritance is regulated to disallow a title to pass to another realm. Assertion of the ruler's sovereignty on titles also enables fabricating brand new claims on foreign titles.
Balanced
Absolute Sovereignty

The ruler is allowed to legally seize any hereditary titles independently of circumstances. Vassal title inheritance is regulated to disallow a title to pass to another realm. Enhanced sovereignty on titles also enables fabricating brand new claims on foreign titles with great efficiency.
Absolute
Enables the Fabricate Claim action for the realm's chancellor.
Facilitates the fabrication of claims by the realm's chancellor.
Administration
These laws govern how society controls and organizes ownership of property and wealth.
Informal Administration
Informal

Society holds together based on unwritten customs and fluid patronage networks. Rulers rely on personal charisma and the loyalty of one's clients to impose authority. It is the way most of the barbarian world works, and it means that the ruler depends greatly on the loyalty of [Player.GetHerHis] more powerful vassals.
Legal Administration

Society is ruled by a system of written laws, jurisprudence and rulings implemented by local rulers as well as envoys of the central authority. Legal predictability makes it possible for lords to keep the inheritance together to facilitate their dynasty's long-term increase in power and wealth. In this system, there is a tendency for vassals to grow more and more powerful with time if not kept in check.
Legal
Imperial Administration
Imperial

This system of administration relies on a class of unlanded state servants, with a hierarchy of magistrates and functionaries running daily business in the name of the emperor. It allows for a power structure that hands less power to permanently landed vassals.

Allows Enatic-Cognatic succession laws\n
Allows Enatic succession laws\n
Disallows Enatic-Cognatic succession laws\n
Disallows Enatic succession laws\n
Must NOT be of a Sectarian religion\n
